turns.speaker: TRIP
turns.text: Please, sir, don't kick my ass! I'll do anything to get out of a beating!

turns.speaker: LITTLE KID
turns.text: Say, Chongo, perhaps we could use some extra cash for tasty snacks at the KISS concert our weasly friend won't be attending.

turns.speaker: TRIP
turns.text: Two hundred bucks?

turns.speaker: LITTLE KID
turns.text: You heard me, nad breath. My time's precious and I think that's a reasonable price to pay for your sorry life.

turns.speaker: TRIP
turns.text: Look, I want to live, but I don't know where the fuck I'm gonna find two hundred bucks.

turns.speaker: MAN WITH COAT
turns.text: Oh, yeah! You and what army?

turns.speaker: TRIP
turns.text: The KISS Army!

turns.speaker: MAN WITH COAT
turns.text: Gimme your gun, boy!

turns.speaker: TRIP
turns.text: No, you gimme your gun, boy!

turns.speaker: MAN WITH COAT
turns.text: Don't tempt me, I'll shoot!

turns.speaker: TRIP
turns.text: Not if I shoot first!

turns.speaker: MAN WITH COAT
turns.text: I don't even think you have a gun!

turns.speaker: TRIP
turns.text: Neither do I!

turns.speaker: SIMPLE SIMON'S VOICE
turns.text: Simple Simon on the Rock, go caller.

turns.speaker: TRIP'S VOICE
turns.text: Hello? Is this me? I'm Trip. Am I on the air?

turns.speaker: SIMPLE SIMON'S VOICE
turns.text: I should hang up on you right now, but you're the right caller so answer quick or get your battleship sunk. What are the names of the four members of KISS?

turns.speaker: TRIP'S VOICE
turns.text: Gene Klein, Stanley Eisen, Paul Frehley, and Peter...Criscula! Yeah, that's it!

turns.speaker: SIMPLE SIMON'S VOICE
turns.text: Is that your final answer?

turns.speaker: TRIP'S VOICE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SIMPLE SIMON'S VOICE
turns.text: Trip? You just got yourself four tickets and four backstage passes to KISS live at Cobo Hall tonight!

turns.speaker: TRIP'S VOICE
turns.text: I did?

turns.speaker: SIMPLE SIMON'S VOICE
turns.text: Yeah, you did!

turns.speaker: TRIP'S VOICE
turns.text: Yeeeehaaawww!! This is totally fuckin' curly, man! Thank you God!

turns.speaker: SIMPLE SIMON'S VOICE
turns.text: Whoa, easy, Trip, this is radio, not "Taxi Driver." Now listen up cause this next part is crucial. Stay on the line so we can get your full name, information, and...

turns.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
turns.text: Good morning, mongrels!

turns.speaker: AUDIENCE
turns.text: Good morning...

turns.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
turns.text: That's all the gusta you can musta? I said, "Good morning!"

turns.speaker: AUDIENCE
turns.text: Good MORNING!

turns.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
turns.text: Now that's better... but I still sense some students out there... who are AFRAID... just to say GOOD MORNING!

turns.speaker: AUDIENCE
turns.text: GOOD MORNING!

turns.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
turns.text: Are you AFRAID?

turns.speaker: AUDIENCE
turns.text: GOOD MORNING!

turns.speaker: JIM CUNNINGHAM
turns.text: Now that's what I like to hear!  Because too many young men and women today are paralysed by their fears. They give in to their feelings of self-doubt... they surrender their bodies to the temptations of drugs, alcohol and premarital sex. Empty solutions. These are toxic chemicals... and disease-spreading behaviour.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Hi... what's going on here?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Horrible accident. My neighbour... he got killed.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: He got smooshed. By a jet engine.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: What was his name?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Donnie. Donnie Darko.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I feel bad for his family.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Did you know him?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Dr. Monnitoff?

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: Donnie.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I know that this is gonna sound kinda weird... but do you know anything about time travel?

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: So... according to Hawking... wormholes might be able to provide a short cut for jumping between two distant regions of space-time.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: So... in order to travel back in time, you'd have to have a big spaceship or something that can travel faster than the speed of light --

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: Theoretically.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: -- and be able to find one of these wormholes.

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: A wormhole with an Einstein-Rosen bridge, which is, theoretically... a wormhole in space controlled by man.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: So... that's it?

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: The basic principles of time travel are there.  So you have the vessel and the portal. And the vessel can be anything. Most likely a spacecraft.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Like a DeLorean.

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: A metal craft of any kind.

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: What effect do you think this would have on an infant?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Well... the thing is, nobody remembers their infancy. And anyone who says they do is lying. We think that this would help develop memory earlier in life.

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: Did you stop and think that maybe infants need darkness? That darkness is part of their natural development.

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: Each vessel travels along a vector path through space-time... along its centre of gravity.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Like a spear.

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: Beg pardon?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Like a spear that comes out of your stomach?

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: Uhh... sure. And in order for the vessel to travel through time it must find the portal, in this case the wormhole, or some unforeseen portal that lies undiscovered.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Could these wormholes appear in nature?

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: That... is highly unlikely. You're talking about an act of God.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: If God controls time... then all time is pre-decided. Then every living thing travels along a set path.

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: I'm not following you.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: If you could see your path or channel growing out of your stomach, you could see into the future. And that's a form of time travel, right?

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: You are contradicting yourself, Donnie. If we could see our destines manifest themselves visually... then we would be given the choice to betray our chosen destinies. The very fact that this choice exists... would mean that all pre-formed destiny would end.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Not if you chose to stay within God's channel...

turns.speaker: DR. MONNITOFF
turns.text: Donnie, I'm afraid I can't continue this conversation. I could lose my job.

turns.speaker: SAMANTHA
turns.text: When can I squeeze one out?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Not until like... eighth grade.

turns.speaker: SAMANTHA
turns.text: Why do I have to sleep with Donnie? He stinks.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: When you fall asleep tonight, I'm gonna fart in your face.

turns.speaker: SAMANTHA
turns.text: I'm telling Mom.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: What happens if you tell Mom and Dad about this, Samantha?

turns.speaker: SAMANTHA
turns.text: You'll put Ariel in the garbage disposal.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: "The Last Unicorn!" By Samantha Darko.

turns.speaker: SAMANTHA
turns.text: Donnie! Give it back!

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: Did you tell them that I flooded the school?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I didn't say shit.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: That's not what I heard. Now they think I did it.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Well, if you're innocent, then you have nothing to worry about.

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: You know what? I think that you did it.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Dea ex machina...

turns.speaker: SETH
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Our saviour...

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: How can you do that?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I can do anything I want... and so can you...

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Why did you make me flood the school?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We just want to guide you in the right direction.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Who is... we?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You'll know soon enough.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Where did you come from?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Do you believe in time travel, Donnie?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I want to show you something.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You have to do something for me first.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You have a request?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yeah. Tell me why you're wearing that stupid bunny suit.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Why are you wearing that stupid man suit?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Take it off. I want to see you.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: What happened to your eye?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I am so sorry.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Why do they call you Frank?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It is the name of my father... and his father before me.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: How much longer is this gonna last?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You should already know that.  Watch the movie, Donnie. I have something to show you.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: DARKO CHEATS DEATH! Man... you're famous! I called you, like, a jillion times last night!

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: We went to a hotel.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: My dad said he found you on the golf course. Are you sleepwalking again?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I don't wanna talk about it.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: How old is Grandma Death?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: A hundred and one, I think. Every day she does the same thing. But there's never any mail.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: What'd you do, Donnie? What'd you do!

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Go home. Go home and tell your parents that everything is going to be just fine.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Hey...

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Hey...

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: School's cancelled.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Wanna walk me home?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Don't look so freaked.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I'm not. But you should check your backpack 'cause those guys like to steal shit.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Fuck them.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: So... you just moved here?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Yeah. My parents got divorced. My mom has a restraining order against my stepdad.  He has... emotional problems.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Oh, I... have those too.  What kind of problems does your dad have?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: He stabbed my mom four times in the chest.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Wow. Did he go to jail?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: He fled. They still can't find him.  My mom and I had to change our names and stuff. I thought Gretchen sounded kind of cool.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I'm sorry. I was in jail once.  I accidentally burned down this house. It was abandoned. I got held back in school again. Can't drive until I'm eighteen.  I think when I grow up I want to be a painter. Or maybe a writer or maybe both. Then I'll write a book and draw the illustrations like a comic book. You know, change things.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Donnie Darko is a cool name. Sounds like a superhero.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: What makes you think I'm not?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: I should go. For physics. Monnitoff says I have to write an essay on the greatest invention ever to benefit mankind.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: That's easy. Antiseptics.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I mean, the whole sanitation thing. Joseph Lister... 1895. Before antiseptics there was no sanitation, especially in medicine.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: You mean soap?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Don't knock soap. Without it, disease would spread rapidly. If we ran out... you and I would never live to see the year 2000.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Wonder where we'll be then.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: The best thing about soap is that it's the only thing on earth that can never get dirty. No matter what crap you throw on it... it always rubs off. And there it is again... perfect.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Until it withers away.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It's a good thing the school was flooded today.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Why is that?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: We never would have had this conversation.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: You're weird.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: That was a compliment.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Will you go with me?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Where are we going?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: No... I mean, will you GO with me? That's like... what they call it here. Going together.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: I'm going home.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: So when you sleepwalk, can you remember afterward? Like, do you dream?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: No. I just wake up and I look around, try to figure out where I am... how I got there.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: My dad said never wake a sleepwalker... because they could drop dead.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It's like this big force... that's in your brain. But sometimes it grows bigger... and it spread down into your arms and legs... and it just sends you someplace.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: So when you sleepwalk, you go somewhere familiar?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: No. Every time I wake up somewhere different. Sometimes my bike is laying there next to me. Like once when I woke up on the edge of this cliff up on Carpathian Ridge.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: And you'd never been there before?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Donnie?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Do you ever feel as though there's always someone watching you?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Well... maybe someone is, like... giving you these dream steroids. And sleepwalking ...is someone showing you the way.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: What happened to your neck?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I don't want to talk about it.  So what happened to your neck?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Babies cry because they're afraid of the dark. And because they have no memories... for all they know... every night could be the last forever. Like, perpetual darkness.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Why not just buy your baby a night light?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: That's not good enough. You've got to go back in time and take all those hours of darkness and pain and replace them... with whatever you wanted.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: With, like, images?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Like... a Hawaiian sunset... the Grand Canyon. Things that remind you how beautiful the world can be.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You know... we've been going together for a week and a half...

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: And what?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: You want to kiss me...

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: That's alright... I understand.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: No... Donnie, wait. I've never...

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I always wanted it to be at a time when... when it reminds you how beautiful the world can be.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Yeah. And right now there's some fat guy over there watching us.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: We're moving through time.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: They suspended me for two days.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Are you okay?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I've been seeing stuff... a lot of really messed-up stuff.  Do you know who Grandma Death is?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: The old crazy woman who lives off Old Gun Road.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Oh, yeah.  "The Philosophy of Time Travel". What is this?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: She wrote it.  There are chapters in this book that describe the stuff I've been seeing. It can't just be a coincidence.  Will you come see her with me?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I know she's here. She never leaves the house.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Maybe she's asleep.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: So, we call them... IMGs.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Infant Memory Generators.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yeah. So the idea is that... you buy these glasses for your infant, and they wear them at night when they sleep.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: And inside these glasses are these slide photographs. And each photograph is of something peaceful... or beautiful. Whatever pictures the parent wants to put inside.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: What? How long was I asleep?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: The whole movie. Let's go.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You want to skip fourth period and go to the Ridge?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: What's wrong with you?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Will you please talk to me?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Not now, Donnie. It isn't a good time.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Then when? I have to talk to you.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Hey. You OK?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: My mom is gone.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Where is she?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: I don't know. She didn't leave a note. The house is all messed up.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: But you're OK?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Did you call the cops?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Yeah, they told me to get out of the house.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: I'm so scared... I just keep thinking that something awful has happened. It's my fucking stepdad. I know it.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It's safe here.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: There's something you have to know, Gretchen.  Everything is going to be just fine.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Come with me.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Where are we going?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Time is running out. We have to go see Grandma Death. We have to talk to her.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Why? Is this about the book?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: No. Frank.

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Who's Frank?

turns.speaker: GRETCHEN
turns.text: Is that a cellar door?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I'm sorry, Ms. Farmer, I just don't get this.

turns.speaker: MS. FARMER
turns.text: Just place an X in the appropriate place on the Lifeline.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I just don't get this. Everything can't be lumped into two categories. That's too simple.

turns.speaker: MS. FARMER
turns.text: The Lifeline is divided that way.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Well, life isn't that simple. So what if Ling Ling kept the cash and returned the wallet? That has nothing to do with either fear or love.

turns.speaker: MS. FARMER
turns.text: Fear and love are the deepest of human emotions.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Well, yeah... OK, but you're not listening to me. There are other things that need to be taken into account here. Like the whole spectrum of human emotion. You're just lumping everything into these two categories... and, like, denying everything else.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: People aren't that simple.

turns.speaker: MS. FARMER
turns.text: If you don't complete the assignment, you'll get a zero for the day.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Will you still be working at Yarn Barn? 'Cause that's a great place to raise children.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: No, a year of partying is enough. She'll be going to Harvard this fall.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You're such a fuck-ass.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: When did you stop taking your medication?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Oh, please tell me, Elizabeth, how exactly does one suck a fuck?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: We will not have this kind of language at the dinner table.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I wish I knew where you went at night.  Did you toilet paper the Johnson's house?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I stopped rolling houses in the sixth grade, Mom.  Get out of my room.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: You know... it would be nice to look at you some time... and see my son. I don't recognise this person today.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Then why don't you start taking the goddamn pills?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Grandma Death.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: That is a terrible nickname.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: He can't, Samantha. He's been suspended from after-school activities. Donnie... are you still with us?  How was your therapy session tonight?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Fine. You know, Dr. Thurman isn't so bad a lady. I can tell her anything.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I have to take the girls to Los Angeles tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Do you get to meet Ed?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: If I'm lucky.  So... I won't be back until the first. Your dad will be back on Sunday, so I've put Elizabeth in charge until then. She has the car... so she can drive you to your therapy tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: How does it feel to have a wacko for a son?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: It feels wonderful.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: So how was school today?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It was great. We had peanut-butter sandwiches and apples and honey at snacktime. And then during show-and- tell, my stuffed walrus was a big hit.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Good Lord.  So the construction guys say it'll take about a week to fix the roof. Damn airline better not fuck us on the shingle match.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Do they know yet?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Know what?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Where it came from?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No... apparently they can't tell us what happened yet. Something about a matching serial number that got burned.  But I had to sign a form saying I wouldn't talk to anyone about it.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: So we're not supposed to tell anybody what nobody knows?

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You tell Dr. Thurman whatever you want.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Oh, shit!

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Grandma Death.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Grandma Death.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You know, Roberta Sparrow. We almost hit her with the car the other day.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You're right. Roberta Sparrow was famous for her gem collections. Kids used to try and steal stuff from her all the time. Over the years... as she got older, she became more and more of a recluse... now she just likes to stay up there all by herself.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I guess she just lost faith in the world.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Who's been giving you weird looks?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: A lot of people. Teachers. Younger kids. It's like they're afraid of me for some reason.  But that's OK... because I know I deserve it.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: You're my only son...

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I know, Dad.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: I know I'm not the best... communicator.  But whatever happens in your life... whatever obstacles you come up against... you just say... and do whatever is in your heart. You be honest... and tell the truth... even if they look at you funny... and they will. They'll tell you that you're wrong. They'll call you a fool.  But what you've got to understand, son, is that almost all of those people are full of bullshit... and they're scared of people like you. Because you're smarter than all of them.

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Donnie Darko, perhaps, given your recent brush with mass destruction, you can give us your opinion?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Well... they say it right when they are ripping the place to shreds. When they flood the house. That like... destruction is a form of creation. So the fact that they burn the money is... ironic. They just want to see what happens when they tear the world apart.  They want to change things.

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Who is Frank?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: A six-foot-tall bunny rabbit.

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: And when the other rabbits hear of Fiver's vision, do they believe him?  It could be the death of an entire way of life, the end of an era.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Why should we care?

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Because the rabbits are us, Donnie.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Why should I mourn for a rabbit like it was a human?

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Is the death of one species less tragic than another?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Of course. A rabbit is not like us. It has no history books... it has no knowledge of sorrow or regret. I like bunnies and all. They're cute... and they're horny. And if you're cute and horny... then you're probably happy that you don't know who you are... or why you're even alive. But the only thing I've known rabbits to do is have sex as many times as possible before they die.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Ms. Pomeroy... what's going on?

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Donnie... it's Friday. Shouldn't you be off with your friends, scaring old people?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: I don't know. That's a good question... but suffice to say that I am no longer your English teacher. They fired me.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: That's bullshit. You're a good teacher.

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Thank you, Donnie. And you're a good student. Lazy... but a good student. Unlike most of the others, you question Mom and Dad's rules.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: What do I tell the rest of the class when they ask about you?

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Tell them that everything is going to be just fine.  It is up to the children to save themselves these days. Because the parents... they don't have a clue.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: What's "Cellar Door"?

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: A famous linguist once said... that of all the phrases in the English language, of all the endless combinations of words in all of history... that "Cellar Door" is the most beautiful.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Cellar door.

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Sometimes it's the only thing that keeps us going.

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: So... will Donnie find his Cellar Door?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I think I already have.  But now she won't even talk to me.

turns.speaker: MS. POMEROY
turns.text: Then go find her, Donnie. Don't let her get away.  She was right about the rabbits. Go.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Your mother said that you've been skipping cycles of your medication.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I've been taking it. I just like to make her feel guilty for all of this. You know, abuse her. Psychologically.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: All of this... certainly isn't your mother's fault, Donald.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: So, I met a new friend.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Would you like to talk about this friend?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: His name is Frank.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Frank.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I think he saved my life.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: How so?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Don't you watch the news?

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: I don't own a television.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: A jet engine fell on my house... landed on my bed. While I was talking to Frank on the golf course.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Frank... instructed you... to get out of bed... just before this happened.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: He said to follow him.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Follow him where?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Into the future.  Then he said that the world was coming to an end.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Do you believe that the world is coming to an end?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: No.  That's stupid.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: And when I clap my hands twice, you will wake up. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: So, tell me about your day, Donald.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I met a girl.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: What is her name?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Gretchen. We're going together now.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Do you think a lot about girls?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: How are things going at school?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I think about girls a lot.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: I asked you about school.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I think about... fucking a lot during school.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: What else do you think about during school?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I think... about... "Who's the Boss?"

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Who is the boss?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I just turn the volume down and think about fucking Alyssa Milano.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: What about your family, Donnie?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: No, I don't think about fucking my family. That's sick!

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Donnie... I want to hear about your friend Frank.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: How many times have you seen Frank?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Four times... so far.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Can anyone else see him?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I don't think so. It's like a TV station. And they're tuned into mine and no one else's.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Who is they? Is Frank part of some larger group?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I don't know. Gretchen has a theory. That Frank is a sign. I told her I thought it was ridiculous.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: A sign from whom?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I think that Frank wants me to go to this woman.  She wrote a book about time travel. Frank asked me if I believed in time travel. That can't just be a random coincidence.  My dad almost hit her with the car the other day, and she said the creepiest thing. She said that every living creature on this earth dies alone.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: How does that make you feel?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It reminded me of my dog Callie.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Is Callie still around?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: No. She died when I was eight. We couldn't find her for days. She went and crawled underneath our back porch...

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Do you feel alone right now?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I'd like to believe that I'm not... but I've just never seen any proof. So I just choose not to bother with it. It's, like, I could spend my whole life thinking about it... debating it in my head. Weighing the pros and cons. And in the end, I still wouldn't have any proof. So... I don't even debate it any more. Because it's absurd.  I don't want to be alone.  So, does that make me, like, an atheist?

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: No. That makes you keep searching.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: And they grow out of our stomachs?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It was just like she described them in her book. Like they were alive. The way that they looked... moved... smelled. They were like workers... assigned to each one of us.  I followed my spear... and I found something...

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: What did you find?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Have you told Gretchen about the spears?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yeah, but if I told her about the other stuff about Frank...

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Are you embarrassed by these things that you see?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: You know... every week I come in here and I tell you stuff... and it's all embarrassing. I tell you stuff that I don't tell anyone else... and you know what? It's your turn, Dr. Thurman. I'm not saying anything else until you tell me something embarrassing about yourself.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Whoa.  That's OK, Dr. Thurman, it's nothing to be embarrassed about. I have sexual fantasies all the time too.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I mean... Gretchen... She won't even let me kiss her. She says because it's our first kiss... she's, like, waiting for this big... moment or something. I just don't get it. I just want to get it over with so we can move on to the good stuff.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: The good stuff.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yeah... you know...  Fucking.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Have you ever made love, Donald?

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: And when I clap my hands together twice, you will wake up. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: So, your parents... why did you disappoint them?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I... I was playing with fire.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Is it Frank who wants you to destroy the world, to set the world on fire?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: People get hurt.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: But it was an accident. The house was under construction.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: People get hurt. I don't want to hurt anyone.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: But you were punished.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yes. I went to jail.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Do you wish that you were punished by your parents instead?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: They... didn't buy me what I wanted for Christmas that year.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: What did you want for Christmas that year?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Hungry Hungry Hippos.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: How did you feel... being denied those Hungry Hungry Hippos?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Regret.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: What else makes you feel regret?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: That I did it again.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: You've done it again?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Yes. I flooded my school... and I burned down that pervert's house. I think I only have a few days left... before they catch me.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Why did you do these things, Donnie? Did Frank tell you to commit these crimes?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I have to obey him... because he saved my life. He controls me and I have to obey him or I'll be left all alone... and I'll never figure out what all of this means...

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: If God exists?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I think now that he might...

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Because I'm so horny.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: God exists because you're horny.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I think so. I think that's one of the clues. It's a clue that tells us... to keep going.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Where are we going?

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Where are we going, Donald?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I have the power to build a time machine.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: How is that possible?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Grandma Death will teach me how. Soon.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Then how is time travel possible?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It would have to be God's portal. They will lead me to it. Then I will go back in time... and I won't feel regret anymore.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: When will this happen?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Soon. Time is almost up.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: What is going to happen?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Frank is going to kill.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Who is he going to kill?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: I can see him right now!

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Where is he, Donald?

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: He's right there... He can read my mind and he'll show me the way out of this. The sky is going to open up... and then He will reveal himself to me.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: If the sky were to suddenly open up... there would be no law... there would be no rule. There would only be you and your memories... the choices you've made and the people you've touched. The life that has been carved out from your subconscious is the only evidence by which you will be judged... by which you must judge yourself. Because when this world ends, there will only be you and him... and no one else.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: It's too late. I've already ruined my life.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: You will survive this... Donald. I promise you that you will survive. You must let me help you.  And when I clap my hands together, you will wake up.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Your medication. They're placebos. Just pills made out of water.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Donald, an atheist is someone who denies altogether the existence of a God. You are an agnostic. An agnostic is someone who believes that there can be no proof of the existence of God... but does not deny the possibility that God exists.

turns.speaker: DONNIE
turns.text: Goodbye, Dr. Thurman.

turns.speaker: DR. THURMAN
turns.text: Goodbye, Donald.
